NATIONAL EDUCATION ASSOCIATION OF THE UNITED STATES
1201 SIXTEENTH STREET NORTHWEST. WASHINGTON 6. D. C.
December 18, 1953
Mr. Graydon Ausmus, President
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
Box 2002
University, Alabama
Dear Graydon:
I recall your eloquent remarks about the need for study and experiment
in the use of educational television as a supplementary aid to classroom
instruction. I was especially appreciative of your comments because the
NEA is asking the Fund for the Advancement of Education to finance a three-
year project in this very field. It is the one, of course, in which the
National Education Association has a tremendous stake and for which our
organization is uniquely qualified. Centered here are all of the types
of administration in nearly every subject field of education and all of
the service groups who might in any way have an interest in television for
the classroom. We propose to represent these fields on a commission and
to have a staff to work on it, if the money is granted by the Fund for the
Advancement of Education. We have some reason to believe that the request
will be granted.
In order to make it clear to the Fund that there was an urgent need for
such a project, we asked a number of people to write to the Fund outlining
the need of such a study from their own point of view. Among these were:
Mrs. Newton Leonard, President, National Congress of Parents and
Teachers
James E. Allen, Jr., Deputy Commissioner of Education, State
Department of Education, Albany, N. Y.
Mark C. Schinnerer, Board of Education, Superintendent of Schools,
Cleveland, Ohio
F. E. Engleman, Commissioner of Education, Hartford, Conn,
Edward Tuttle, Executive Secretary, National School Boards Ass'n
Edgar Fuller, Executive Secretary, National Council of Chief S^ate
School Officers
Their letters are now on file with the Fund for the Advancement of Education.
I am writing to ask if you will not, in the same eloquent fashion as you
performed last Wednesday, write to Alvin C. Eurich, Vice President, The
Fund for the Advancement of Education, 575 Madison Avenue, New York 22,
New York, in behalf of such an appropriation. So that you may get a better
picture of what we are asking for and what some of the others have done to
encourage the Fund, I am sending you my original letter to the Fund together
with one of the supporting letters sent.
